entry.title: Gaining Operational Insights with the SAP LogServ Workbook on Microsoft Sentinel - Part 4
entry.content:
Find your way to our central blog series entry here.

Dear community,

Following our previous deep-dives into LogServ usage with Microsoft Sentinel for SAP and customization, let's explore the operational insights available through Sentinel's built-in workbook for SAP LogServ monitoring.

Near real-time visibility atyYour fingertips

The SAP LogServ Insights Dashboard on Azure transforms raw log data into actionable intelligence. Navigate to Microsoft Sentinel > Workbooks > Templates and locate the pre-configured dashboard. 

 

Save to your workspace and open to get started. Make sure to select the Log Analytics workspace powering your Sentinel tenant first.

 

 

Key metrics that matter

The workbook provides comprehensive monitoring across four critical dimensions:

  • Total Events: Track log ingestion volumes (4M events shown)
  • Active Systems: Monitor connected hosts (36 active systems)
  • Data Freshness: Near real-time status indicators with color-coded alerts
  • Log Distribution: Understand log ingestion patterns across your SAP landscape components

The Log Volume Timeline reveals ingestion patterns, helping identify peak usage periods and potential anomalies. Notice how the 24-hour view shows consistent data flow with the characteristic SAP workload patterns.

Pay attention to the status legend: Fresh (green), Recent (orange), Older (red), and Stale (dark red). These indicators help SAP Security and SOC teams quickly assess data currency - critical for incident response.

The workbook automatically refreshes, ensuring your security operations center maintains current visibility into your SAP RISE environment's log ingestion health.

Proactive Alert Configuration

Transform workbook insights into actionable alerts using the Create Alert Rule button visible above the timeline. This creates Azure Monitor alerts directly from your LogServ metrics, enabling threshold-based notifications for critical scenarios like data ingestion anomalies or system connectivity issues. Configure alert rules to monitor total event volumes, data freshness status changes, or active system counts falling below expected baselines.

Azure Monitor's alert engine integrates seamlessly with action groups for email, SMS, Microsoft Teams, or webhook notifications to your operations team. For detailed configuration guidance, reference the Azure Monitor alerts documentation.

 

For those of you who prefer PowerBI for dashboarding...

See this Microsoft Learn article how to craft a dashboard from the Microsoft Sentinel queries for SAP LogServ.

 

Final Words

That’s a wrap🌯. You saw today how to observe log ingestion health and use data freshness indicators for your SAP LogServ solution in Microsoft Sentinel. The built-in views are easy to extend and customize for your own individual needs.

#Kudos to @Hemanth_Kusampudi and team for the partnership.

Get started with your deployment from here today.

What visuals are most helpful for your daily operations? Do you want special breakdowns for HANA database, and proxy components like the SAP WebDispatcher? Let us know in the comments or reach out directly.

Cheers Martin & Hemanth

entry.title: Key User Custom Fields: Maximum number of fields and characters
entry.content:
Key User Custom Fields: Maximum number of fields and characters

Have you ever wondered how many key user custom fields you could add to a specific business context? If so, this blog post is for you.

This blog post covers the following topics:

  • The maximum number of key user custom fields you can add
  • The maximum overall number of characters consumed by key user custom fields

Please note that for all S/4HANA editions, the actual numbers for the maximum fields and maximum overall number characters supported strongly depend on the S/4HANA release. In general, the maximum number of fields and the maximum overall number of characters consumed by key user custom fields have been significantly increased over time.

S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

In S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, you can figure out easily how much capacity for a given business context is left. This is directly shown while creating a new field using the Custom Fields app (see screenshot below).

Business Context Capacity

The field “Business Context Capacity” displays a percentage number telling you which percentage of the overall available capacity reserved for customers has already been consumed. When you hover over the “Business Context Capacity” bar, you see how many fields and how many bytes are available (see screenshot). As a rule of thumb, you can divide the number of bytes by factor 2 to get the free number of characters.

Also you can see the remaining capacity when you open the value help on the business context field of the “New Field” popup and then on the very right column you see the remaining capacity for the business contexts listed (see screenshot below).

Business Context Capacity shown in Business Context value help

Please note that for each business context, the responsible SAP application department defines the capacity available for customers individually. The only guard rail that exists is that the number of fields reserved for customers is never less than 100 fields and never less than 1000 characters.
If the available business context capacity is not sufficient for you, please create a request via the customer influence channel or create a customer ticket on the application component of the respective business context.

S/4HANA and S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition

In S/4HANA and S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, the business context capacity limits are not considered at all. You can add key user custom fields until you reach the technical limits given by ABAP dictionary. As soon as you reach these limits, you'll no longer be able to add additional key user custom fields. A popup will tell you that there is no more space left to create key user custom fields.

These limits are very high. For SAP_BASIS releases above 7.95, no customer has reached these limits yet.

The ABAP dictionary limits relevant in this context are:

  1. The maximum number of fields: the maximum number of fields supported in a database table. Note that for counting them, it's not relevant whether this field is a SAP standard field or not
  2. The maximum table width: this figure tells you how many bytes at max per table entry in a database table are supported. Note that for counting them, it's not relevant whether the bytes originate from a SAP standard field or not

Let’s have a look at these limits:

  1. Maximum Number of Fields
    • A database table can have up to 749 fields by default
    • Since SAP-BASIS release 7.73, the limit increases to:
      • 1,500 fields for application tables with a 'Column' storage type.
      • 1,000 fields for application tables with a 'Row' storage type
    • Since SAP-BASIS release 9.16, the limit has been further increased to:
      • 3000 fields for application tables with a 'Column' storage type
      • 1,000 fields for application tables with a 'Row' storage type (remained unchanged)
  2. Maximum Table Width
    • By default, the maximum width of a table is 4,030 characters
    • With the TABLEN feature activated (DDIC table DD02L, field TABLEN_FEATURE), the limit increases to 16,293 characters
    • Since SAP-BASIS release 7.95, the table width limit has been extended further to 256,000 characters

With this, we are done. I hope this blog helps you understand what the limits of key user custom fields are regarding number of fields and number of bytes.

Feedback, Comments, or Questions:

You’re cordially invited to provide them in the comments section below. Please follow my profile to get updates when I publish more posts on these topics.
Feel invited to post and answer questions here (https://answers.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26) and read other posts on the topic (https://blogs.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26/).

I want to thank Yasmina van Rooij (YasminavanRooij), Karsten Schaser (Karsten_Schaser) for their extremely helpful contributions.

Other related blog posts (just a small selection of the blogs available for custom field extensibility)

  • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/convert-manually-created-append-fields-to-real-key-user-custom-fields/ba-p/13967399
  • https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/key-user-custom-fields-in-s-4hana-cloud-private-edition-and-on-premise-dos/ba-p/14026871

entry.title: Commitments in focus: How SAP S/4HANA is changing the management of financial commitments
entry.content:
What does commitment mean in the SAP context? 

Commitments describe the outstanding financial obligations of a company. These include, for example, orders, provisions or approved but not yet utilized funds. Although no payment has yet been made, these items impact liquidity, budgeting and risk assessment. 

SAP records such obligations in the system in several modules, in particular in Materials Management (MM), Financial Accounting (FI) and Controlling (CO). It is precisely at this interface that SAP S/4HANA’s decisive advantage emerges. 

GRAPHIC 1: Schematic overview of commitment processing between MM, FI and CO 

From static reporting to real-time insight 

SAP ECC already offered the option of managing commitments. However, the flow of information was often sluggish, fragmented and poorly integrated. Analyses were based on upstream reports that rarely reflected the current data situation. 

SAP S/4HANA solves this problem with real-time data processing. Every relevant transaction, be it an order, an investment application or a provision, is immediately recorded in the system and can be analyzed instantly. The underlying SAP HANA database ensures that data is not only quickly available but also intelligently linked. 

Comparison of COOI and ACDOCA: the evolution of commitment management 

A key difference between SAP ECC and SAP S/4HANA lies in how financial obligations are managed and mapped. In SAP ECC, the COOI table (open orders, accruals and commitments) played a central role in commitment management. This table recorded open items and provided an overview of financial obligations but was often static and limited in terms of updates. 

With SAP S/4HANA, commitments are managed via the ACDOCA table. This central financial accounting table offers several advantages: 

  1. Real-time data processing:
    ACDOCA enables the recording and evaluation of transactions in real time. This means that every change is immediately reflected in the system, resulting in an up-to-date and accurate representation of financial obligations.      
  2. Integrated data structure:
    In contrast to the fragmented data management in ECC, ACDOCA integrates data from different modules and processes, providing a more comprehensive overview of financial obligations and their impact on the organization. 
  3. Extended analysis functions:
    With the ACDOCA data, organizations can perform complex analyses, such as plan/actual comparisons and trend analysis, which were previously difficult to carry out. This enables targeted management of the financial strategy and early identification of potential risks.     
  4. Flexibility and adaptability:
    ACDOCA's modern data structure supports easy adaptation to increasing requirements and the integration of new technologies such as AI-supported analyses and forecasts.     

This transition from COOI to ACDOCA clearly illustrates how SAP S/4HANA has advanced commitment management and supports companies in not only recording financial commitments, but also actively managing and strategically utilizing them. 

 GRAPHIC 2: Comparison of the commitment functionality in SAP ECC and SAP S/4HANA 

 

Advantages of real-time data processing in SAP S/4HANA: 

  1. Application example - supply chain management:
    A company uses SAP S/4HANA to monitor its stock levels in real time. By recording orders and deliveries immediately, it can react more quickly to changes in demand and avoid bottlenecks. This leads to more efficient warehousing and reduced storage costs.
  2. Case study - Financial planning:
    A company in the energy sector implements SAP S/4HANA to gain real-time insight into its financial obligations. By immediately recording investment requests and provisions, the company can plan its liquidity more accurately and identify financial risks at an early stage. This leads to improved strategic decision-making and optimized budget management.     
  3.  

A new level of integration and analysis 

Another milestone is the seamless integration. SAP S/4HANA not only links MM, FI and CO technically, but also creates a unified view of obligations. This means that not only individual items, but also comprehensive budget evaluations or plan-versus-actual comparisons are possible at the touch of a button. 

At the same time, modern analytics functions offer new insights. Companies can recognize trends, identify anomalies at an early stage and make decisions based on reliable figures. 

Explanation of the Fiori interface and its advantages: 

The SAP Fiori interface offers a modern, intuitive and responsive design that greatly simplifies access to SAP applications. Users benefit from a role-based user experience that takes their specific tasks and needs into account. This enables a personalized and efficient way of working, as users can quickly access the information and functions relevant to their role without having to navigate through complex menus and transactions. The Fiori interface is particularly beneficial for users without in-depth technical system knowledge, as it facilitates the use of SAP applications and increases productivity through clear visualizations and simple interactions.  

GRAPHIC 3: SAP Fiori dashboard with current commitment values 

 

Exposure in the project business: actively managing cash flow 

Commitments have a particularly strategic impact in the project environment. SAP S/4HANA makes it possible to update payment obligations assigned to WBS elements, networks and orders, automatically and with precise value types. This creates the basis for project-related liquidity planning based on actual obligations. 

Down payments, allocations and project-related target/actual comparisons can also be clearly mapped. The ability to adjust financial items as required also increases flexibility. 

GRAPHIC 4: Project-oriented commitment process from the WBS element to the commitment 

Concrete implementation and specific functions of SAP S/4HANA 

User-friendliness thanks to the Fiori interface  

A key difference in the implementation of commitment management between SAP ECC and SAP S/4HANA lies in the use of the modern Fiori interface, which enables more intuitive and user-friendly interaction. This interface supports a role-based and personalized user experience, allowing users to work efficiently without in-depth system knowledge. 

Use of intelligent functions for commitment management  

In addition, SAP S/4HANA offers specific functions such as AI-supported forecasting models that help to better manage future obligations and identify risks at an early stage. These models use historical data and probabilities to provide automated decision-making tools that significantly simplify commitment management. 

Technical implementation with CDS views and virtual data model 

In order to make optimum use of the functions and forecasting models mentioned, a robust database is required. The available CDS views in particular play a central role in analyzing the commitments. The content provides a manageable selection of CDS views that can be used to analyze the obligations. In the project context, it is advisable to check the associated virtual data model (VDM) and the definition of the key figures to see whether they reflect the requirements of the specialist area. This may result in expansion requirements that need to be mapped in the customer's own CDS views. In particular, when combining data from the two tables COOI and ACDOCA, it must be checked how these are merged. 

What's next? A look at the roadmap 

The development of SAP S/4HANA is far from complete. The upcoming releases promise, among other things, AI-supported forecasting models for commitment management. Automated decision-making aids based on historical data and probabilities will further reduce the burden on day-to-day business. 

A lot is also happening in terms of user-friendliness. The continuous improvement of the Fiori apps ensures that both controllers and project managers can work efficiently with commitments without in-depth system knowledge. 

Conclusion: Managing commitments, not just recording them 

Commitments not only show what a company has already incurred. They are a mirror of future expenditure and therefore an early warning system for the company's finances. SAP S/4HANA takes this tool to a new level by combining real-time data, integrated processes and dynamic analysis functions with modern implementation approaches and specific functions. With the Fiori interface and AI-supported forecasting models, commitments is transformed from a mere booking value into a strategic management tool. Companies that rely on these new possibilities can monitor commitments more specifically, manage budgets more precisely and identify financial risks earlier. The key to this lies in the intelligent use of existing data and a system that makes this data available in real time and in a user-friendly way. 

But that's just our view. How does your company perceive these changes? What experiences have you had with the implementation and use of SAP S/4HANA in commitment management? We look forward to hearing your perspectives and discussing new solutions together.

entry.title: Convert Key User Custom Fields to ABAP Managed Fields (AMF)
entry.content:
Introduction

Have you ever been in the situation that you created a key user custom field and then, when wanting to change the metadata of the field, the change turned out to be only supported by ABAP Managed Fields? 

If your answer is yes, then this blog post is just for you. In this blog, you'll learn how to convert a “normal” key user custom field to an ABAP Managed Field. With that, you can do all the changes supported by ABAP Managed Fields.

You can refer to this blog for an introduction into ABAP Managed Fields.

Let's say that you created a key user custom field of type “Code List”. You want to change the code list values directly in the production system instead of maintaining them in the development system and then transporting them over to the production system. You can refer to this blog for a comprehensive overview of custom field types providing a value list.
There may also be other reasons why you want to transform a key user custom field to an ABAP Managed field. Some of these reasons could be that:

  • you want to change the case sensitivity flag of the domain of your key user custom field from case sensitive to not case sensitive
  • you want to have a specific conversion routine within the domain of your key user custom field 
  • you want to specify a certain DDIC search help or check table

Please note that this blog  exclusively addresses SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA On-Premise and doesn’t address SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, as the feature of ABAP Managed Fields is not available in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

 

Convert a key user custom field to an ABAP Managed Field

Let’s assume you created, published and transported a key user custom field ZZ1_AssignedDepartment of type "Code List" of length 11 on the Sales Order business object (business context is SD_SALESDOC) where the code list consists out of three values (“Department1”, “Department2”, “Department3”).

Key user custom field creation for custom field ZZ1_AssignedDepartment

Several weeks after using the field in the production system, you may find that you want to change the code list values directly in the production system. This approach avoids maintaining these values in the development system and transporting them to the production system.

A more complicated approach to changing the code list values directly in the production system is to create a custom business object and use it in a new key user custom field of type “Association to Business Object”, since the data of custom business objects can be entered directly in the production system. You can transport the custom field along with all other development objects needed. As a next step, you create a report and class(es) in order to let you migrate the data from the old custom field to the new one.
The development effort for such a migration is significant, and it's even worse if you've already used the exposed old custom field in an integration scenario. You'd have to change everything there, too, as the name of the custom field changes.

Starting from S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2023 and On-Premise 2023, there is a new functionality that lets you convert the already existing key user custom field of type "Code List" to an ABAP Managed Field.
When you do this for a "Code List" field, the generated code value table, the code description table, the value help view, the value help description view, the data element, the domain, and the persistence include append all are preserved, but detached from the custom field itself. They're now under your manual control. This way, the code list values and descriptions are no longer part of the transport objects belonging to the custom field.
To be able to maintain the code values and code description values, there are multiple options:

  • create a maintenance view and maintenance dialog on top of the two persistence tables 
  • create a RAP application on top of these two persistence tables

In this blog, we'll show you the first option. Let's say you created a custom field ZZ1_AssignedDepartment. To convert this custom field to an ABAP Managed Field, and to make sure that the value help values can subsequently be maintained in the production system, follow this blog.

1. Open field ZZ1_AssignedDepartment in transaction SCFD_FIELDVIEWER

Open transaction SCFD_FIELDVIEWER in the system and client where you created the key user custom field ZZ1_AssignedDepartment. You'll see a list of all key user custom fields in that system. Double click the custom field ZZ1_AssignedDepartment.
When you go to the Enhancements tab on the field detail screen, you'll see the list of enhancements which have been generated for this particular key user custom field (see screenshot below). These enhancements all belong to this one custom field and can't be changed manually.

List of enhancements belonging to the custom field

2. Convert field ZZ1_AssignedDepartment to an ABAP Managed field

The next step is to click on the “Convert to ABAP Managed Field” button on the top left of the screen (see screenshot below). Make sure that the custom field you want to transform has been selected before on the left side of the screen.

Click on “Convert to ABAP Managed Fields” button

A popup will be shown asking you whether you “really want to convert the field to an ABAP managed field? The action is not reversible”. Click "Yes" to start the conversion process. As soon as the conversion has run, a respective success popup is shown.

Conversion success popup

Let's have a look at what happened behind the scenes during the conversion process:
Once again, have a look at the Enhancements tab of the custom field.

List of enhancements belonging to the custom field after the transformation

The list has become much shorter than before. The reason for that is that seven of the generated objects do now no longer exclusively belong to the custom field, but have been detached from the custom field and became independent development objects. These development objects are still used by the custom field, but can now be changed manually with the respective DDIC low-level tools, for example. These objects are:

      • Code Value Table: ZZ1_513D258A0759    
      • Code Description Table: ZZ1_EA4F9E9F7B2F     
      • CDS Code Value View: ZZ1_ASSIGNEDDEPARTMENT_V               
      • CDS Code Description View:  ZZ1_ASSIGNEDDEPARTMENT_W               
      • Data Element: ZZ1_ASSIGNEDDEPARTMENT               
      • Domain: ZZ1_ASSIGNEDDEPARTMENT
      • Persistence Include Append: ZZ1_VRTNU6KIWGDFIEIAVO2GXBFNTQ

With this transformation, the former custom field became an ABAP Managed Field as if it had been created from scratch as an ABAP Managed field using transaction SCFD_EUI. For this ABAP Managed Field, the same rules apply as for any other ABAP Managed field. The following two blogs dive deeper into ABAP Managed fields and address the specifics of them (especially regarding software logistics):

      • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/convert-manually-created-append-fields-to-real-key-user-custom-fields/ba-p/13967399
      • https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/key-user-custom-fields-in-s-4hana-cloud-private-edition-and-on-premise-dos/ba-p/14026871

There is one more aspect to consider in case you want to transform a CodeList custom field to an AMF field. The code values and the code description values are no longer part of the transport object of the respective field. They do now only exist locally in the respective system and must be maintained in each system individually (but note: this is exactly what we wanted to achieve).

3. Create a maintenance view and a maintenance dialog for the code value and the code description table

The next step is to create a maintenance view for the code value table and the code description table. On top of this maintenance view, a maintenance dialog should be created. You can learn how to do this in the following blog: https://community.sap.com/t5/application-development-and-automation-blog-posts/getting-started-with-abap-how-to-create-maintenance-view/ba-p/13533494

Follow these steps to, for example, create the maintenance view ZZ1_DEPMNT_MV.

4. Maintain the code and the code description values using the maintenance view

Using the maintenance view ZZ1_DEPMNT_MV, you can now create, maintain, and delete entries for the two tables  ZZ1_513D258A0759 and ZZ1_EA4F9E9F7B2F. You can do this by navigating to the maintenance view using SE11. Click on Contents (see screenshot below).  The old values that you've maintained using the custom fields tool are preserved.

Maintain code values and code description locally using a maintenance view

Please note that the descriptions are maintained in table ZZ1_EA4F9E9F7B2F using the login language as language so you don't have to enter the language manually.

With this, you are done. You successfully transformed the key user custom field to an ABAP Managed Field. As a consequence, you no longer have to maintain the value help values (codes and descriptions) in the development system and transport them over to the target system. Now, you can maintain the values directly in the local system itself.

Please note that using a maintenance view in order to maintain the value help values (codes and descriptions) is just one possibility out of many. You could, for example, also create a RAP application on top of the code and description tables in order to create and maintain the value help values.

Now, you are done! Congratulations!
With this, you’re now equipped to convert a key user custom field to an ABAP Managed Field.

Please note that for the following field types of custom fields, a conversion to an ABAP Managed field is not supported:

  • “Amount with currency”
  • “Quantity with unit”
  • “Code List based on CDS View”
  • “Association to Business Object”

If you try to convert a field with this field type, you'll get an error popup telling you that the conversion for type [field type] is not supported.

Please note that this blog has been elaborated by a team of experts. I want to thank Yasmina van Rooij (YasminavanRooij), Karsten Schaser (Karsten_Schaser) and Christian Fuhlbruegge (ChristianFuhlbruegge) for their extremely helpful contributions.

Feedback, Comments, or Questions

You’re cordially invited to provide feedback, comments, or questions in the comments section below. Please follow our profiles to get updates when we publish more posts on these topics.
Feel invited to post and answer questions here (https://answers.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26) and read other posts on the topic (https://blogs.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26/).

Other related blog posts

  1. Convert Manually Created Append Fields to Real Key User Custom Fields 
  2. Key User Custom Fields in S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and On-Premise: Dos and Don’ts
  3. How to implement a custom field of type “Code List based on CDS view” with a developer extensibility... 
    How to implement a custom entity in the ABAP RESTful Programming Model using remote function modules    
  4. SAP Screen Personas: How to position key user custom fields exactly where you want them to be

entry.title: News from SAP Activate SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and more
entry.content:
We are pleased to announce the availability of the updates to SAP Activate and share exciting news – the launch of Joule in SAP Activate road map viewer – for customers, partners, and SAP internal users. We are also excited about the new visual design of the home page in the road map viewer and the updated user experience. This release introduces several exciting updates to the implementation guidance across a range of SAP Activate assets. We continue to aim to streamline and improve the implementation process, providing a more seamless experience for our valued users. Here are the key highlights for this release:

  • NEW - Enhance Your SAP Activate road map viewer Experience with Joule
  • Revamped Visual Design for the SAP Activate road map viewer
  • NEW - SAP Activate provisioning road map for SAP Business Suite packages
  • SAP Activate Community Blogs and Activate Minute Videos
  • Updates to SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • Updates to SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private Edition
  • Updates to SAP Activate for SAP Business Technology Platform
  • Updates to SAP Activate for Conversion of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2-system to 3-system landscape
  • Updates to SAP Activate for SAP SuccessFactors
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Test Automation Tool 2508 Release

Enhance Your SAP Activate road map viewer Experience with Joule

We are thrilled to share that Joule is now generally available in the SAP Activate road map viewer. With Joule, customers, partners and SAP internal users can quickly ask Activate related questions and receive clear, helpful answers – making it easier to unlock the full value of SAP Activate.

Joule is available to all SAP for Me users and currently supports two of our most widely used road maps:

  • SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private – New Implementation
  • SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (3-system landscape)

To learn more about how to interact with Joule, check out the blog post here.

 

Revamped Visual Design for the SAP Activate road map viewer

We’ve enhanced the onboarding experience for new users of the SAP Activate road map viewer by introducing a fresh visual design, updated guidance, and built-in onboarding resources right on the home screen. Learn more about these improvements in this blog post. 

 

NEW SAP Activate provisioning road map for SAP Business Suite packages

We’re excited to announce the release of a dedicated SAP Activate provisioning road map for SAP Business Suite packages. This new resources is now available to customers in the road map viewer, and you can find more details in the blog post here.

 

SAP Activate Community | SAP Activate Blogs | SAP Activate Minute Videos

Join the SAP Activate Community to explore valuable content and resources while connecting with SAP partners, clients and internal colleagues by participating in discussions and sharing knowledge.

Make sure to follow the SAP Activate tag to access blog posts like those highlighted here, along with additional insights shared by SAP Activate experts within the community.

Recap of some blog posts from the community:

  • New Road Maps for SAP Business Network - Supplier Portal Private Edition and Commerce Automation by Ana Goetze
  • Key Enhancements to the SAP Fieldglass Road map by Ana Goetze
  • Learn Quickly via the SAP Activate Minute Videos by Dan Ciecko
  • Planning your System Conversion to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition following SAP Activate by Jose Marquez Mares
  • Security, Data Protection and IAM guidelines in SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition by Kiran Bose
  • Accelerating Implementation with SAP Activate in the Public Cloud by user pranavgarud
  • Guiding Your Cloud Journey: The New SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Adoption Plan Roadmap by Christina Galbreath
  • Unlocking Innovation: Understanding SAP’s Clean Core and Its Benefits (for IT Leaders) by user arpin
  • Explore the SAP Activate Methodology using a reimagined Road Map Viewer by Ana Goetze
  • NEW SAP Activate provisioning road map for SAP Business Suite packages by Adnette Kamugisha

 

Updates of SAP Activate for SAP S/HANA Cloud Public Edition in 2508

The SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (3-system landscape) implementation roadmap has been enhanced based on product management input, system functionality changes, and customer feedback. Below are highlights for this release.

  • Introduced a new road map, SAP Activate for Cloud ERP, to guide customers through a cloud ERP implementation. This road map is the continuation of the Provisioning Enablement for SAP Cloud ERP road map and will be expanded to include all the products in the business suite packages.
  • Added road maps, SAP Business Network for Commerce Automation and SAP Ariba, to the combinable road map list in SAP Cloud ALM. This allows for better flexibility when implementing functionality related to the business suite packages.
  • Added a new deliverable, Introduction to SAP Business Suite, and three new tasks to the Discover phase to support learning about the SAP Business Suite along with the GROW with SAP and Rise with SAP journeys.
  • Added references to SAP WalkMe to increase visibility on how SAP WalkMe can help during the implementation.

 

Updates of SAP Activate for Cloud ERP Private Edition

The SAP Activate Methodology content for SAP Cloud ERP Private Edition continues to be enhanced to help guide the customer through the journey of a new implementation, system conversion, and selective data transition following the SAP Clean Core principles. These journeys are accessible by selecting the appropriate journey tag within the single roadmap in road map viewer or individually in SAP Cloud ALM.

Key highlights include:

  • In coordination with the Regional Implementation Group (RIG), several updates have been made in the roadmaps for SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private - New Implementation. 
  • The Discover phase has been updated with a new deliverable Introduction to SAP Business Suite Discover Phase and three new tasks Understand your SAP Cloud Journey, Review the SAP Business Suite Offering and Try SAP. These new tasks aligned with the new Business Suite messaging and content on the sap.com. 
  • All the transition scenarios now include WalkMe Premium guidance and project implementation can leverage the WalkMe as a digitial adoption platform to help enhance user onboarding and enablement throughout their transformation journey. Learn more by reviewing the WalkMe product tag.   
  • During System Conversion customers can leverage the RISE with SAP System Transition Workbench, a tool that offers a single, highly automated, guided system transition processes that integrates all essential technical activities and tools. Learn more by reviewing the SAP Blog - Introducing the RISE with SAP System Transition Workbench.
  • Several updates made to the Data Management workstream, with updated tasks, description, procedure steps and updated accelerators. 
  • In the past few releases, we made updates to the Project Management workstream. The updates include enhanced description of key deliverables, tasks and accelerators and improve workflow efficiency and ensure consistency across project lifecycle. 

 See the release notes for a complete list of all improvements.

 

Updates of SAP Activate for SAP Business Technology Platform

We’re excited to announce the release of new content designed to support customers in the following topics:

  • Implementation of SAP Integration Suite capabilities - It offers a structured approach that leverages best practices, tools, and methodologies to support end-to-end integration project lifecycles — from discovery and planning to implementation and go-live.
  • New content to help assist customers with the migration from SAP Process Orchestration (SAP PO) to the modern, cloud-based SAP Integration Suite and covering the following aspects of the migration project
    • A phased migration approach tailored to your landscape
    • Best practices for analyzing and refactoring integration content
    • Tooling support and checklists for assessment and execution
  • End-to-end implementation guidance for SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) application development capabilities. This content supports teams in identifying business cases, selecting the right cloud development models, and successfully designing, building, and deploying applications using SAP BTP.

 

Updates of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2-system landscape to 3-system landscape 

We are excited to share the latest improvements to the SAP Activate guidance for our SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition customers converting from a 2-system landscape to a 3-system landscape. Since the last major release in January, we have made several updates to the guidance based on our learnings from conversion projects. The key updates are outlined below:

  • Added guidance for the use of the Parallel Line capability after the conversion to the 3-system landscape. This includes the self-enablement tasks in the Prepare and Run phases as well as a new task redirecting to the Parallel Line content in SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, 3-system landscape. (link)
  • Added new task Request Activation of Scope Item 5XU to Use SAP Document and Reporting Compliance into the Prepare phase to trigger the activation checks earlier in the conversion process. (link)
  • Updated task Activate Scope Item 5XU to Use SAP Document and Reporting Compliance in the Realize phase. (link)
  • Added new task, Validate IT contact prior to contract signature, to the Discover phase to ensure the IT contact is available during the conversion weekend. (link)
  • Updated task Create SAP for Me case to allow SAP proactively check your environment to indicate that part of the procedure is only intended for Solution Builder based cases. (link)
  • Added new task, Fix the affected workflows to the Realize phase with instructions on how to fix and re-transport the workflows. Including new accelerator Help - Flexible Workflow - Agent Rules that is added to the task (link)
  • Added a new task, Copy Missing Business Roles from Production System to Test System, to the deliverable Initial System Access After Conversion, to copy business roles from the production tenant to the test tenant when they are missing.

We recommend that you review the detailed release notes in the SAP Activate road map viewer for the latest content updates and view the conversion overview video here. Additionally, bookmark the SAP Community page dedicated to conversion topics here.

 

Updates of SAP Activate for SAP SuccessFactors

The SAP Activate for SAP SuccessFactors roadmap has been enhanced based on product management input, system functionality changes, and customer feedback. Below are the highlights:

  • Updated phase/workstream graphic to reflect the current deliverable structure in the road map.
  • Expanded the Baseline Activation Service for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and SAP SuccessFactors road map by adding SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central.
  • Updated the several tasks in the Project Management workstream to be consistent and combinable with other road maps.
  • Added references to SAP WalkMe to increase visibility on how SAP WalkMe can help during the implementation.

 

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Test Automation Tool 2508 Release

The 2508 release introduces significant enhancements to the Test Automation Tool (TAT) for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, with a focus on improved usability and intelligent navigation. Key highlights include:

  • Enhanced Post Upgrade Tests Dashboard
    • Advanced Filtering: Easily filter results by Test Plan, Release, Process Type, Status and Application Area
    • Focused Analysis: Reduce information overload and quickly access relevant data
    • Faster Decision-Making: Improved data visualization for faster analysis
  • Joule Navigation Integration
    • Universal Access: Joule navigation is now available across all TAT applications
    • Seamless Movement: Deep links enable effortless movement between test automation modules
    • Prompt-Based Access: Quickly open any TAT app using intuitive prompts

These enhancements greatly boost testing efficiency, minimize manual navigation, and increase user productivity throughout all test automation workflows.

For more details, refer to the blog on the 2508 features in the Test Automation Tool.

 

Run simple – SAP Activate – Accelerate and simplify the adoption of SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

entry.title: Earn your badge for downtime-optimized Conversion
entry.content:
You’re looking for a deep dive into downtime-optimized system conversion to SAP S/4HANA?

📢I have excellent news for you!

The system conversion to SAP S/4HANA, potentially combined with a move to the Cloud, elevates your company the text level Enterprise Resource Planning. As the system conversion is not just another software upgrade, the project needs additional considerations such as the Simplification Item Check. Check out the SAP Readiness Check for SAP S/4HANA Conversion to start your system analysis.

As soon as you're ready for the technical execution, Software Update Manager 2.0 will be the tool of choice. After your first system conversion of a sandbox system, you might wonder how to optimize the downtime required for the event.

Check out the Technical Downtime Optimization App as a starting point for runtime analysis! 📈📉

Quickly you'll stumble across downtime-optimized conversion approach of Software Update Manager. This is THE approach if you're looking for reducing the downtime of a system conversion and database migration. The approach offers amazing time-saving potential by moving part of the data migration to uptime (downtime-optimized Database Migration Option) as well as moving part of the data conversion to uptime (🤫 Psst, you may get a glimpse on potential time savings in the Technical Downtime Optimization app simulation.) This savings come with additional phases and aspects of planning compared to a standard system conversion.

To have you well prepared for this, it is mandatory to dive into the details of downtime-optimized conversion before using the approach.  To do so, the SAP Learning Journey Minimizing downtime of System Conversion to SAP S/4HANA with downtime-optimized Conversion of Software Update Manager  is available to let you get to know the approach at your own pace and free of charge!

👉 Check it out: Minimizing Downtime of System Conversion to SAP S/4HANA with Downtime-optimized Conversion

After completing the SAP Learning Journey and passing all quizzes, you'll receive a knowledge badge which is necessary to register your downtime-optimized conversion project at SAP. For anyone following this approach since some time: This Learning Journey replaces the instructor-led training ADM329. Any badges out of the training stay valid. ✅

🎓Take some time for your education and let me know what you think!

entry.title: SAP Master Data Integration (MDI) – Bank and Cost Center Replication from S/4HANA
entry.content:
In continuation of my previous blogs on MDI Architecture and Deployment and Business Partner Replication, this post focuses on Bank and Cost Center replication from an SAP S/4HANA system to SAP Master Data Integration (MDI).

Master Data objects like Banks and Cost Centers are foundational across multiple systems. Enabling seamless replication to MDI ensures a harmonized master data landscape, supporting a clean core and extensible architecture.

Common Configuration Steps

Before configuring the replication-specific models, there are common prerequisites applicable to both Bank and Cost Center integration. These ensure secured, authenticated communication and connectivity between S/4HANA and MDI.

1. OAuth 2.0 Client Configuration

Use transaction OA2C_CONFIG to configure your OAuth 2.0 client. This allows S/4HANA to authenticate securely with the SAP MDI service.

2. Create RFC Destination

Use transaction SM59 to create a destination pointing to MDI, essential for connectivity.

3. Configure MDI Destination

Use transaction S_SAL_71000052 to access view V_MDI_DEST_CONF and configure your destination here.

4. BGRFC Configuration

Set up Inbound BGRFC Destinations using SBGRFCCONF. This ensures reliable communication for asynchronous data transfers.

5. Extract AIF Content

Run /AIF/CONTENT_EXTRACT with SAP_COM_0659 to extract the content needed for integration scenarios.

6. Publish OData V4 Services

Use /IWFND/V4_ADMIN to publish OData V4 service groups if not already done.

7. Create Technical User

Use SU01 to create a user that will be used for background processing and secure calls.

8. Assign Required Role

Clone the role SAP_CA_DRF_MDO using PFCG and assign it to the technical user created above.

9. Configure SAP BTP Destination

Ensure the destination is correctly set in the SAP BTP Cockpit pointing to your S/4HANA On-Prem system.

Cost Center Replication Setup

A. Push Model Configuration

Configure a push model to automatically send data to MDI when a Cost Center is created or changed.

B. Pull Model Testing

To validate the integration, use a REST client such as Postman to pull data from MDI after the Push model replicates it.

Sample replicated Cost Center data can be verified in Postman once changes are triggered from S/4HANA.

C. Output Test

Bank Replication Setup

A. Push Model Configuration

Similar to Cost Center, set up a Push Model for Banks to send data changes automatically to MDI.

B. Pull Model Testing

Again, Postman can be used as a mock target system to verify the successful pull of replicated bank data from MDI.

C. Output Test

Summary

With this setup, you’ve now enabled real-time or near-real-time replication of Bank and Cost Center data from S/4HANA to SAP MDI, supporting both Push and Pull models. This ensures data consistency across systems and promotes a modular, scalable enterprise data architecture.

Please note the Blog is to connect S/4HANA on-prem/Private Cloud system to MDI, there can be more scenario where the MDI would be then connected to other systems. For such scenarios, configuration is required in Master Data Orchestration or Business Data Orchestration.

More Blogs:
SAP Master Data Integration (MDI): Architecture, D... - SAP Community
SAP MDI: SAP S/4HANA Business Partner Replication using DRF Customizing - SAP Community

entry.title: Accelerate Your SAP S/4HANA Journey with Selective Data Transition Engagement (SDTE)
entry.content:
Accelerate Your SAP S/4HANA Journey with Selective Data Transition Engagement (SDTE)

This article is the first in a series exploring Selective Data Transition Engagement (SDTE). In upcoming article, we will dive into methodology, scenario selection, tooling, and more to demystify SDTE and showcase its value.

Modern enterprises are under constant pressure to innovate and optimize. For those running on SAP ERP, transitioning to SAP S/4HANA is a significant milestone - but how can you preserve your past investments that give you a competitive edge while embracing the latest technology and use the chance to optimize processes? SAP S/4HANA Selective Data Transition Engagement (SDTE) is specifically designed to address this challenge. By retaining what sets you apart, and standardizing areas where it makes sense, SDTE offers a flexible, efficient path to transformation.

 

Business Challenge

Balancing Differentiation and Standardization

Enterprises running SAP ERP have often spent years - or even decades - developing custom processes, industry-specific extensions, and unique reporting. These innovations are competitive differentiators that users rely on every day. At the same time, core "commodity" processes (Finance, Procurement, Manufacturing, HR) can gain dramatically from standardized best practices baked into SAP S/4HANA. The fundamental tension: How do you preserve what sets you apart while embracing the efficiency and innovation that come with a modern digital core?

Reducing IT Burden and TCO

Maintaining multiple legacy systems - each with its own data archives - drives up infrastructure costs, complicates backups and restores, and hampers analytics. As organizations plan moves to cloud offerings like RISE with SAP, every gigabyte contributes to ongoing subscription and storage expenses. Selective data transition helps by consolidating landscapes, cleansing aged records, and migrating only what truly matters - slashing total cost of ownership (TCO).

Ensuring Business Continuity

Prolonged downtime windows and sprawling, multi-year pre-projects erode user confidence and delay the realization of business benefits. CIOs, CFOs, enterprise architects, and process owners all share one goal: modernize without bringing the business to a halt. An effective migration strategy must keep business impact to a bare minimum while delivering a future-proof digital core.

 

The SDTE Solution - A Flexible, Targeted Approach

Unlike a one-size-fits-all implementation or a straightforward system conversion, SDTE offers a customer-specific roadmap:

  • Selectively Retain Data that remains relevant for analysis or compliance, while discarding obsolete or low-value data.
  • Incorporate Process Harmonization right away, without needing to spin off separate, time-consuming pre-projects.
  • Preservation of Custom Differentiators Carry forward the custom processes and extensions that users depend on, while standardizing commodity processes to leverage SAP S/4HANA best practices.
  • Adopt Modern, Standardized Practices for commodity processes, speeding up efficiency gains in finance, supply chain, and beyond.

Reduce System Footprint for the Cloud

When you move to the cloud, every gigabyte matters. By migrating only the relevant data, you can effectively reduce system footprint, cut storage costs, and ensure you don't drag inefficiencies into your new SAP S/4HANA landscape. At the same time, you'll feed AI-driven scenarios with the best, most accurate historical data - enabling predictive maintenance, more refined demand planning, or improved financial forecasting.

Consolidate Landscapes and Unlock Value

SDTE also excels at landscape consolidation - merging multiple ERP systems into a single SAP S/4HANA instance. This not only simplifies ongoing maintenance and upgrades but also improves transparency for reporting and analytics. Companies that take advantage of this flexibility experience significant cost savings and faster ROI.

Faster Time-to-Value

A hallmark of SDTE is its ability to eliminate or shorten many pre-projects, such as separately addressing finance harmonization or data cleansing. Because these transformations can be integrated into the main migration event, your organization realizes business benefits more quickly - with less effort from end users and fewer touchpoints for potential disruption.

 

Technical Detail

How Does the Engagement Work?

SDTE projects build on SAP Activate, enriched with SDTE-specific checkpoints:

  1. Discover
    Your business processes, data volumes, and future vision are analyzed to see what exactly needs to be transformed or left behind.
  2. Prepare
    A targeted plan is set up, detailing which data to migrate or cleanse. Tools and technical environments are installed to enable secure, high-performance data transfers.
  3. Explore and Realize
    Agile iterations test the migration rules, verifying that the relevant data is selected and transformed. Customizations are preserved where necessary, and processes are standardized where they are beneficial.
  4. Deploy/Run
    With SDTE variety of data migration approaches including minimized downtime approaches, your move to SAP S/4HANA can be scheduled over a weekend or other minimal business-impact window. Rigorous testing ensures everything functions smoothly.
  5. Quality Gates
    Throughout these phases, SDTE methodology includes checkpoints to maintain high standards, reduce risk, and ensure you are on track.

 

Tools, Principles, and Best Practices

  • Flexible Migration Approach: SDTE supports multiple different migration approaches like posting and table based. By default high-speed data transfer that bypasses application-level constraints, letting you harmonize or map data according to your new structures and preserve historical data.
  • Integration of Cleansing and Enrichment: Legacy data can be enriched, ensuring that your new system fuels modern capabilities like AI and advanced analytics.
  • System Landscape Consolidation: SDTE partners bring proven methods to merge or split SAP systems, helping you standardize reporting, unify master data, and gain complete transparency.

 

Success Stories

Pharmaceutical Company (Global): Data Footprint Reduction and Faster Time-to-Value

Customer consolidated an 85 TB ECC environment into a streamlined S/4HANA landscape, selectively retaining five years of history (down from 27) and migrating just 427 of 1,100 company codes. By combining landscape consolidation, selective retention, and finance harmonization in a single project, the customer accelerated value delivery and minimized disruption.

SDTE Properties in Action:

  • Landscape Consolidation: Multiple organizational units merged into one unified system.
  • Data Footprint Reduction: Historical data pruned by 80%, shrinking the HANA footprint.
  • Faster Time-to-Value: Combined disparate initiatives into one go-live event.

Chemicals Company (Japan): Phase approach and Full migration of historical data

The transition to the new system required migrating full historical data, including data archives from the SAP ERP application to SAP S/4HANA to realize data continuity for a set of company codes. Furthermore, the customer had to plan for and then execute various data conversions and codification changes in its general ledger accounts, materials numbers, profit centers, and so on to meet the data management requirements of the new system

SDTE Properties in Action:

  • Selective Data Retention: Only a set of company codes moved, legacy archives remained untouched.
  • Phased approach: Project split in multiple phases allowing flexibility and reducing the impact on the customer team,
  • Process Harmonization: various data conversions in general ledger accounts, materials numbers, profit centers to meet the data management requirements of the new system

 

Vision: The Future of Data Migration and Beyond

AI-Driven Efficiency

As artificial intelligence evolves, expect even more automation of data mapping, cleansing, and harmonization. AI can swiftly identify inconsistencies, propose corrective actions, and optimize transformations - lowering manual effort and reducing errors.

Standardization at Scale

With AI and continuous improvement, standards for data migration become more universal, making it easier to share best practices and lessons learned. This streamlines future transformations while reducing costs and risks.

Addressing the Resource Shortage

IT transformation skills are scarce, but AI-driven acceleration can help bridge the gap. Automated rule generation and scenario testing mean teams can get more done with fewer specialized resources.

As a result, IT can shift from a cost center to a genuine business enabler - fueling innovation rather than being bogged down by legacy systems.

 

Call to Action

You have seen how SDTE preserves your unique differentiators, modernizes core processes, and accelerates your move to a lean, cloud-ready SAP S/4HANA environment - while laying the foundation for AI-powered operational excellence.

Next in our series: As SDT encompasses a variety of pathways rather than a single one, our upcoming article will explore SDT Scenario Selection, focusing on:

  • SDT Scenarios Overview: Discussing the best practice SDT scenarios that are available and commonly used in projects.
  • Key Decision Drivers: Identifying the factors that influence the selection of the optimal SDT scenario for your transformation

In the meantime:

  1. Explore Webinars and Resources
    Discover more about SDTE via official SAP Support Portal webinars or community sessions that dive deeper into the specifics.
  2. Contact the SDTE Community
    Reach out to the expert group of SAP and its partners for an assessment of your current landscape. They can help identify how selective data transition can best fit your needs.
  3. Start Your Transformation
    Do not wait until maintenance windows close or all experts are not available anymore. A well-planned selective data migration can future-proof your IT environment and jump-start your intelligent enterprise journey.

Take the next step by visiting
SDTE Engagement Overview
to connect with the SDTE community and chart out your custom path to SAP S/4HANA success.

entry.title: Empowering Business Users with Personalized News in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 Release
entry.content:
Keeping business users informed about system and company news is essential for organizational success. When users are aware of changes that could impact their daily tasks, they can make better decisions, adapt more quickly, and boost overall productivity. Staying up to date—especially with updates on processes, departments, or system changes—helps eliminate confusion and ensures alignment across teams.  

While our existing news feed provides valuable updates on SAP system changes, we’ve listened closely to customer feedback and enhanced communication and user experience on My Home even further. In the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release, we now offer the ability to customize and manage the My Home news feed through the new Manage News application.

Manage News Application

 

Introducing the Manage News Application 

The Manage News application empowers news administrators to deliver timely, targeted information updates directly to business users via a centralized news feed. 

Key capabilities for news administrators include: 

  • Create, manage, and publish news articles: Administrators can compose news posts to be displayed on My Home, controlling the flow of critical company and system updates. 
  • Control visibility and importance: News items can be marked as critical, ensuring essential information is highlighted and receives appropriate attention from business users. 
  • Plan and schedule communications: Administrators can organize when specific news should be published, enabling timely and organized delivery of updates. 
  • Language adaptation: Messages can be tailored in all company-supported languages, ensuring effective communication across diverse user groups. 
  • Targeted audience assignment: News can be assigned to specific App Transaction codes, so only users with access to the corresponding Fiori apps or transaction codes will see relevant news items. 
  • Organize news by groups or categories: News articles can be grouped into categories such as Finance or Human Resources, making it easy for users to find pertinent information. 
  • Visual enhancements: Administrators can upload images aligned with news topics to make posts more engaging and visually informative. 

News article creation in Manage News Application

 

What Business Users Will Experience 

The My Home news feed now displays articles created by news administrators, neatly organized into designated categories. Critical updates are clearly marked with an eye-catching critical marker to ensure users notice and prioritize these messages. 

This personalized news feature centralizes essential communications in one place, tailored to the needs of each user based on their system app access. By delivering relevant, timely information directly to business users, organizations can foster a more informed and agile workforce. 

 Critical News displayed in My Home News Feed 

Critical News Article in My Home News dialog

 

Benefits for Your Organization 

With the Manage News application, administrators can tailor the news feed to reflect the specific needs of your company or organization, enabling more effective communication with business users. This streamlined and targeted approach to information sharing helps: 

  • Improve user awareness and decision-making 
  • Minimize confusion and misalignment across teams 
  • Increase adaptability to system or process changes 
  • Enhance overall company performance 

 

Prerequisites 

To access the Manage News application users or administrators will have to be assigned to the SAP_CORE_BC_CUX_NWS_MNG_PC business catalogue. For business users to view the news feed on My Home they will have to be assigned SAP_CORE_BC_CUX_NWS_DSP_PC catalogue. The SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition SAP_BR_EMPLOYEE role will already have SAP_CORE_BC_CUX_NWS_DSP_PC business catalogue assigned. With the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release, news maintained in the Manage News application will be displayed by default for all customers who have not configured a RSS feed or SAP Custom System News. To display the news from the Manage News application the 'Manage News App' setting needs to be enabled via UI Adaptation mode (Adapt UI in the User Actions menu). Users or administrator must have the catalog SAP_CORE_BC_EXT_FLEX attached to their role to access the UI Adaptation key user capabilities. 

My Home UI Adaptation Mode News Feed Settings

 

We’re excited to bring this powerful new communication feature to you with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release and look forward to seeing how it helps your business stay connected and informed. 

If you are interested in hearing about the latest innovations in SAP Cloud ERP, please join our Public Cloud Practitioner Forum in which SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition customers share best practices and provide feedback to the SAP development teams about new functionality. 

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/public-cloud-means-continuous-innovation-and-continuous-learning-new-user/ba-p/14017362 

(Open to SAP Cloud ERP customers, including partners running SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.) 

Caroline Welsh, and Suneet Agarwal  on behalf of the SAP UX Foundations responsible for My Home in SAP S/4HANA.

Overview

Prerequisites

Our SAP Learning Experts will get back to you as soon as possible! 
We are here to support you.

entry.title: Post Asset Retirement as of OP2025 Private Cloud Edition with Universal Parallel Accounting (UPA)
entry.content:
Purpose

As of OP2025 Private Cloud Edition with UPA, the new Fiori app 'Post Asset Retirement'  has replaced two old, GUI-based apps:

  • Post Retirement (Non-Integrated) - Without Customer
  • Post Retirement - By Scrapping

This article describes the main features of the app, deep-diving into the details by comparing it with its predecessors. It also describes the customization of currency types in General Ledger Accounting (G/L), as well as analysis on some errors caused by impropper setups there.

Business Transaction Type

Similar to what you do in the Fiori app Post Asset Acquisition, you must enter company code, asset numbers, and a couple of mandatory fields for dates, i.e. Journal Entry Date, Posting Date, and Asset Value Date.

What's more important:  In the section 'Transaction Details', you must choose one 'Business Transaction Type' from the list, to tell the system: Do you want to retire the asset with or without any revenue?

⚠️Business Transaction Type has been introduced since the first Fiori app for asset posting was published, i.e. Post Asset Acquisition. As the successor, Business Transaction Type is much simpler than its predecessor, the traditional 3-digit-code of transaction type, which is not required as an input in any Fiori app for asset posting now.

Posting Parameters

The section 'Posting Data' is the place for you to enter the posting parameters. In the sub-section 'Valuation'', you can choose the ledgers and depreciation areas you that want to post to. ➡️ Once you choose a ledger, the system derives the depreciation areas from the ledger, and vice versa.

⚠️Hint: If you don't choose anything, neither ledger nor depreciation area, you'll post to all ledgers and all depreciation areas that are included in the current asset.

The 'Retirement Type' in the sub-section 'Retirement Details' is one of the most important fields of the app. The system gives you three options as following.

Partial Retirement

All these options are straightforward. However, if you compare retirement types above with those in its predecessor apps, you will find a bigg difference: you have only two options for your partial retirement, by amount or by percentage. 

In other words, the percentage of the partial retirement can only be decided by the amount or the percentage rate manually entered. ➡️ Even if the asset manages quantity, you cannot enter a quantity and ask the system to decide the percentage of the partial retirement from this quantity.

For example, in the current fiscal year, your assset has been capitalized with the amount 12,000 EUR and the quantity 10PC. With the posting parameters below, you will retire it by 50%, but only deduct the quantity by 3PC.

Obviously, in this example above, you only have acquisition postings in the current year. So you must choose 'Current Year'  in the field 'Year of Acquisition'. If you have prior-year acquisitions and you want to retire that part, you must choose 'Prior Year'.

⚠️ Only when you are going for a partial retirement, can you see these fields in the page: Retirement Amount, Quantity, & Year of Acquisition.

Retirement with Revenue

Once you choose the business transaction type 'Retirement with Revenue', some more fields will appear in the section 'Posting Data'.  

Like what you did in the predecessor apps, you can supply the revenue amount with the net book value (NBV) of a given depreciation area. By doing that, you will not generate any P&L effect.

Alternatively, you can manually enter the revenue amount yourself. 

 

⚠️ In this Fiori app, you cannot enter a revenue in any currency. Instead, you can only pick a currency type from the list via Currency Type of Revenue. This is different from the past. 

➡️ To avoid complex UI interaction, Currency Type of Revenue contains a full list of currency types supported by the company code. For example, the company code may support 3 currency types below, and all of them will appear in the list. ➡️  Check out the next chapter for more details about currency types.

  • 10 - Company Code Currency
  • 30 - Group Currency
  • 40 - Hard Currency

If the ledger 4G does not manage 40 (Hard Currency) but you only post your retirement to 4G, on hitting the button 'Display Line Items' or 'Simulate', you will get an error like below.

Customization of Currency Types

Currency Type is a complex setup in General Ledger Accounting (G/L). Asset Accounting is well integrated with G/L, especially with regard to currency types. So, it is worth giving some more words.

First, where can you find the currency types that are being managed by a ledger within a company code?

Run the t-code FINSC_LEDGER, choose a ledger from the node 'Ledger', navigate to the node 'Company Code Settings for the Ledger', and you will find this configuration.  ➡️ Here, in this example, the ledger BU in company code 1010 only supports two customerized currency types: ZU as the local currency type and ZV as the group currency type.

Next, how are those customized currency types related to the standard ones? 

Go to the node 'Currency Type', and check out the individual currency types. ➡️ Here, in this example, you can see that ZU and ZV are actually almost the same things as the standard currency types 10 and 30, but only with a different valuation view type: 3 (Segmentation Valuation). ➡️ In other words, ZU and ZV are just copies of currency types 10 and 30, but they are only designed for Segment Valuation.

Last but not least, which currency types are listed for the revenue amount in the Fiori app F7107?

In this example, the company code 1010 has many ledgers assigned, and with a lot of currency types, as shown in the database table FINSC_LD_CMP (below).

However, only 10, 30, 40 and Z0 are basic ones, a.k.a. 'Legal Currency Type' / 'Plain Currency Type', as shown in the database table FINSC_CURTYPE (below). All other currency types are just different valuations of those legal/plain currency types.

Therefore, the Fiori app only lists those legal/plain currency types for the revenue amount.

Errors about Currency Types

On hitting the button 'Simulate' or 'Post', you will get errors around currency types. Whenever you have this kind of error, most likely you have selected a wrong currency type of the revenue amount. 

One typical example is the error below. You can easily find the reason behind if you have another look at the table FINSC_LD_CMP (screenshot above): company code 1010 and ledger 4G has only defined currency types 11 and 31, whose plain/legal currency types are 10 and 30. And Z0 is not one of them.

Another example, in the screenshot below, the error KM132 states the currency type Z0 and valuation type 2 do not fit together. Then, please go back to check the table FINSC_CURTYPE (see the corresponding screenshot above) once again. ➡️ It is easy to see that no currency type has been defined as a copy of plain/legal currency type Z0 for valuation type 2 ('Profit Center Valuation'). 

Now, you want to retire the asset on BU and OD only. But you still get the error KM132. This time, it states the currency type Z0 and valuation type 3 do not fit together. 

Well, please go back to the database table FINSC_CURTYPE once more. This time the error is about valuation type 3, Segmentation Valuation. Then, the system looks up the table for the entries with 'VALUESUBTYP' (Subtype of Valuation View) BU for the plain/legal currency type Z0. There is no hit at all.

⚠️Corresponding configuration of VALUESUBTYP is inside the currency type settings below. And it is used ONLY for Segmentation Valuation.

Summary

You may have noticed it already that some posting parameters in this Fiori app used to be part of classic, 3-digit-code transaction types. But now, you can directly enter/choose them in the Fiori UI, without being confused by the 3-digit-codes.

Asset Accounting (AA) is well integrated with General Ledger (G/L). Some errors, especially those about ledgers or currency types, are reported from G/L but not AA. It is always helpful to check out the configrations in the t-code FINSC_LEDGER.

In OP2025 Private Cloud Edition with UPA, some other new Fiori apps are delivered as well. You may refer to the following SAP note to check out all those new apps as well as their tiles and busniess catalogs.

3614510 - Business Catalogs and Tiles for Asset Accounting with/without Universal Parallel Accounting in S/4HANA Private Cloud 2025 - SAP for Me

entry.title: Example code for SAP_COM_0466 - Print Queue Item - Read (A2X)
entry.content:
Introduction

This blog focuses on how to get documents out from the SAP Print Queue and how to pass them on to an external Output Management System (OMS) for processing and printing using the SAP provided API. It supplements the already existing blog with example implementation with JAVA code of  SAP_COM_0466 - Print Queue Item - Read (A2X).

Example code for SAP_COM_0466 - Print Queue Item - Read (A2X)

See the details on SAP_COM_0466 | SAP Help Portal how to configure your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system to support Print Queues. 
Prerequisites: 

  • Compiled with SAPMachine 21. You can download here.
  • Download (e.g. here) and add latest version of class org.json 
  • Adapt with your personal connection and access details.  

Please note that code is meant as example how the api can be used. Code is not claimed to be complete, to be error free or to be state of the art programming style. 

Usage of the example code

  1. Download (e.g. here) and add latest version of class org.json 
  2. Adopt cope with your access details
  3. Compile code (I used SAPMachine 21).
  4. Run code
  5. Create a document on the configured print queue in SAP System
  6. Code will  process print queue item
  7. You can also simulate errors on the print queue item. See comments in the code

Remind!
Code is meant as example how the api can be used. Code is not claimed to be complete, to be error free or to be state of the art programming style. Nevertheless feedback is welcome.

import java.net.CookieManager;
import java.net.http.*;
import java.net.URI;
import java.util.Base64;
import java.util.concurrent.*; 
import org.json.*;

class SAP_COM_0466_example {
    
    public static int Get_System_Details(  System_Str[] System_Details ) throws Exception {
    // get details of the SAP sytem for api and other calls
    
        // pre-defined system details and credentials for testing, needs to be configured in SAP system beforehand
        
		System_Details[0] = new System_Str (
            "https://my######-api.s4hana.ondemand.com",                                                        // URL to SAP system DEF
            "SAPUSERNAME",                                                                                     // SAP User Name / Client ID on BTP
            "########################################",                                                        // SAP User Password / Client Secret on BTP
            "SAP S/4HANA CLOUD (Public Edition)",                                                              // SAP System Type
            "dummy",                                                                                           // Sub-Account name, only required for BTP 
            10);                                                                                               // intervall for ICM cache polling

        /*                                                                                       
        System_Details[0] = new System_Str (                                                 
            "https://abc.private.corp",                                                                        // URL to SAP system ABC
            "SAPUSERNAME",                                                                                     // SAP User Name / Client ID on BTP
            "########################################",                                                        // SAP User Password / Client Secret on BTP
            "SAP S/4HANA CLOUD (Private Edition)",                                                             // SAP System Type
            "dummy",                                                                                           // Sub-Account name, only required for BTP 
            10);                                                                                               // intervall for ICM cache polling
        */                                                                                         

        /*                                                                                       
        System_Details[0] = new System_Str (                                                 
            "https://api.eu11.print.services.sap/qm",                                                          // URL to SAP system BTP
            "#############################################################",                                   // SAP User Name / Client ID on BTP
            "#################################################################################",               // SAP User Password / Client Secret on BTP
            "SAP BTP",                                                                                         // SAP System Type
            "icc-btp-test-abcd1234");                                                                          // Sub-Account name, only required for BTP
            10);                                                                                               // intervall for ICM cache polling
        */
     
        return (200);                                                                                          // return good status code
     
    }


    public static int Get_Bearer_Token( StringBuilder BearerToken, String Credentials, System_Str System_Details ) throws Exception {
    // For BTP only to get the bearer token for oauth authentication 

        String       UrlLocator;                                                                               // http request url
        HttpRequest  RequestBody;                                                                              // http request body
        HttpHeaders  RequestHeaders;                                                                           // http request header
        HttpResponse ResponseReply;                                                                            // http reply body
        HttpHeaders  ResponseHeaders;                                                                          // http reply header
        String       ResponseCodeL;                                                                            // http response code
        String       BearerTokenL;                                                                             // BTP bearer token for oauth authentication
        
        UrlLocator = System_Details.SystemUrl.substring(System_Details.SystemUrl.indexOf("api.") + 4);         // extract location of BTP account
        UrlLocator = UrlLocator.substring(0,UrlLocator.indexOf("."));                                 
        UrlLocator = "https://" + System_Details.SubDomain + ".authentication." + UrlLocator + ".hana.ondemand.com"; // build url for bearer token request
        //System.out.println(UrlLocator + "/oauth/token?grant_type=client_credentials");              
                                                                                                      
        RequestBody = HttpRequest.newBuilder()                                                                 // build the http request
